guide.introduction: How to fade between colors with the Common Anode RGB LED, included in Maker Shed's Ultimate Arduino Microcontroller Pack.
guide.introduction_rendered:
How to fade between colors with the Common Anode RGB LED, included in Maker Shed's Ultimate Arduino Microcontroller Pack.

Relevant parts
  • Common Anode RGB LED
  • 330 ohm resistor
  • Jumper Wire

lines.text: Grab all the parts, and begin by plugging the Common Anode RGB LED into your breadboard.
lines.text_raw: Grab all the parts, and begin by plugging the Common Anode RGB LED into your breadboard.

lines.text: Orient it in the breadboard with the red leg on the left, and power leg second from the left.
lines.text_raw: Orient it in the breadboard with the red leg on the left, and power leg second from the left.

lines.text: That's power (long) leg to F42 on the breadboard, with the red leg right next to it in F43.
lines.text_raw: That's power (long) leg to F42 on the breadboard, with the red leg right next to it in F43.

lines.text: Now wire up the positive (longest) lead of the LED to the 5V header on the Arduino.
lines.text_raw: Now wire up the positive (longest) lead of the LED to the 5V header on the Arduino.

lines.text: You can use a jumper from J42 to the Arduino.
lines.text_raw: You can use a jumper from J42 to the Arduino.

lines.text: Connect the three resistors, one from each of the three other LED pins to another spot on the transparent breadboard.
lines.text_raw: Connect the three resistors, one from each of the three other LED pins to another spot on the transparent breadboard.

lines.text: Place one 330 Ω resistor in G43 and G49.
lines.text_raw: Place one 330 Ω resistor in G43 and G49.

lines.text: Place another 330 Ω resistor in H41 and H35.
lines.text_raw: Place another 330 Ω resistor in H41 and H35.

lines.text: Place the last 330 Ω resistor in G40 and G34.
lines.text_raw: Place the last 330 Ω resistor in G40 and G34.

steps.title: Connect the RGB pins to the Arduino

lines.text: Next, connect the three pins of the LED to the Arduino.
lines.text_raw: Next, connect the three pins of the LED to the Arduino.

lines.text: Red goes to PWM Pin 6, from breadboard pin J49.
lines.text_raw: Red goes to PWM Pin 6, from breadboard pin J49.

lines.text: Green goes to PWM Pin 5, from breadboard pin J35.
lines.text_raw: Green goes to PWM Pin 5, from breadboard pin J35.

lines.text: Blue goes to PWM Pin 3, from breadboard pin J34.
lines.text_raw: Blue goes to PWM Pin 3, from breadboard pin J34.

lines.text: Now you can grab the code from GitHub and upload it to your Arduino. Have fun!
lines.text_raw: Now you can grab the code from [https://github.com/Make-Magazine/UMP-Sample-Code/blob/master/rgb_led_lamp/rgb_led_lamp.ino|GitHub] and upload it to your Arduino. Have fun!
